conclusion: To understand how the shadows (A, B, C, and D) will change when the light source moves backward above the objects, we need to consider the principles of shadows and perspective.
Shadow Position: The position of the shadow depends on the relative positions of the light source, the object casting the shadow, and the surface receiving the shadow.
Shadow Size: The size of the shadow is influenced by the distance between the light source and the object, as well as the angle at which the light hits the object's surface.
When the light source moves backward, the light source will be further away from the objects and the surface where the shadows fall.

As the light source moves back, the shadows will move closer to their respective objects because the light has less angle to strike the surface directly in front of each object, thus pushing the shadow closer to the object itself.
When the light source moves backward, it emits light over a wider area, causing the shadows to appear smaller as the light is more diffused across the surface.
The shadows will also become elongated along the direction parallel to the light source, due to the increased distance between the light source and the objects.
